item.title: Cloud vs Premises Contact Center Costs
item.description: Lots of small businesses can get by with just a local or toll-free number for customer calls. But as companies grow, they usually dedicate staff and resources to handle customer interactions, creating a dedicated department known as a contact center. While contact centers are important, they can be expensive to run. Is there a way to reduce the cost? Until recently, outsourcing to different locations was an option, but that often led to issues with language barriers and inconsistent service quality.

item.title: Cheaper Connections To The Cloud
item.description: Businesses are often quick to celebrate the cost savings of cloud services compared to maintaining their own data centers. However, there’s a hidden cost that often catches them off guard: cloud connectivity. The current cost of bandwidth depends on a company’s blend of LAN, MAN, and WAN traffic. Businesses with data centers located in the same building as their employees usually find most of their application traffic stays on the LAN.

item.title: Hosted VoIP Solutions Include New Phones
item.description: Cloud services are changing how we think about technology. Just like server racks are moving to the cloud, so are office phone systems. Traditional PBX systems are being replaced by cloud-hosted solutions. But this transition begs the question: what happens to the physical phone lines? Similar to connecting data servers off-site, a connection called a SIP Trunk links your on-premise network to the hosted PBX. While it’s possible to use existing analog phones with adapters, this approach misses out on the advanced features of Voice over IP (VoIP).

item.title: Backup Your Gmail and Google Apps While You Can
item.description: A lot of us utilize Gmail and other Google services for work due to their ease of use and affordability. However, a major drawback is the lack of robust data recovery options in case of accidental deletions or other mishaps. Imagine accidentally deleting crucial contact information from your Gmail account. Without a backup, that data would be lost forever. While Google doesn’t provide a native backup solution, third-party services like Backupify bridge the gap.

item.title: Virtual Hosted PBX VoIP
item.description: There are many ways to implement VoIP, with some methods being more effective than others. Your goal with VoIP is likely to reduce expenses and access enhanced features while maintaining high-quality voice communication. Achieving this balance is possible with the right technology, though proper setup can be challenging. Getting assistance with the installation, specifically by outsourcing complex aspects to a specialized provider, can greatly increase your chances of a smooth implementation.

item.title: Send Fax From Email On Your Computer or Smartphone
item.description: Do you recall fax machines with thermal paper rolls? Those messages had a distinct look and tended to fade. To preserve them, you’d copy them onto regular paper using a laser printer, then diligently wash the strange residue off your hands. Fax technology has significantly evolved. Thermal paper is out, and even traditional fax machines are becoming rare. Cloud-based electronic transmission and storage are the modern alternatives. Sending and receiving faxes via email is the contemporary approach.

item.title: Enterprise Communications Services To The Cloud
item.description: A significant shift from traditional phone systems to cloud-based communication is happening right now. XO Communications, a leader in this field, predicts 60% of companies will move almost a third of their voice communications to the cloud in the coming years. For a free consultation and quotes tailored to your company’s communication needs, our partners at Telarus offer fast and reliable service from expert product specialists. Contact them at http://www.cloudnetworkingservices.com/.

item.title: Internet Service Without The Outages
item.description: The internet has become an essential tool for accessing information, connecting with others, and conducting business. It offers a vast repository of knowledge, real-time services, and entertainment options. However, internet outages can occur, causing frustration and disruption. While complete internet blackouts are rare, local outages can still happen. These outages can be planned maintenance, accidental disruptions, or natural disasters. For businesses and individuals who rely heavily on the internet, these outages can be costly.

item.title: Gigabit Ethernet vs SONET
item.description: The increasing use of video and cloud services is pushing business bandwidth requirements to gigabit-per-second speeds, necessitating a shift from copper to fiber optic connections. However, there are two primary types of fiber optic bandwidth: SONET and Gigabit Ethernet. Developed by telephone companies, SONET (Synchronous Optical NETwork) was initially designed for transmitting numerous simultaneous phone calls between switching centers, both domestically and internationally. SDH (Synchronous Digital Hierarchy) is its international counterpart, often referenced together as SONET/SDH.

item.title: Stress Testing For Your Website
item.description: You’ve successfully launched your website and initiated a marketing campaign. However, what happens when your website crashes during a surge in visitor traffic? This situation is preventable through stress testing. Many companies neglect this step and suffer the consequences, especially during peak seasons like holidays. Don’t let this happen to you. Load testing allows you to assess your website’s capacity and make necessary improvements. BrowserMob, a cloud-based service, provides affordable load testing for businesses of all sizes.

item.title: Welcome To The Big Bandwidth Era
item.description: Remember the days of big band music? While many may not be familiar with that era, technology has dramatically changed since then. We’ve moved from radio and kilocycles to the digital age with bandwidth measured in Mbps and Gbps. This is the era of big bandwidth. But what exactly qualifies as “big bandwidth”? NuVox, a leading telecommunications company, defines it as any bandwidth exceeding 10 Mbps. This speed is the target for home internet providers as video streaming gains popularity.

item.title: 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet for your Business
item.description: By: John Shepler Are your sophisticated business applications, such as cloud services, big data, VoIP telephony, video conferencing, or even simple video downloads, suffering due to insufficient bandwidth? If so, it might be the perfect time to consider upgrading to a 100 x 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet service. For a quick overview of Fast Ethernet, take a look at this video: Fast Ethernet, offering speeds of 100 Mbps, is just one of many options provided by Carrier Ethernet providers.

item.title: Colocation vs Cloud Services
item.description: The choice between “make” and “buy” is about deciding whether to handle tasks internally or outsource them. IT managers frequently face this dilemma when contemplating between managing an on-site data center and opting for a colocation facility. Now, there’s a third option: the cloud. While both colocation and cloud services are obtained from external providers, the differences between them are significant from an operational standpoint. Colocation facilities shine by offering a physical space designed for IT needs.

item.title: Big Data Needs Big Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler Bandwidth is expanding at an incredible rate. Currently, a major infrastructural development is the shift towards 100 Gbps (100 GigE) wavelength services for national and international connections. It seems like only yesterday Gigabit Ethernet was a new concept, impractical for most businesses. These days, GigE is a basic requirement in some fields. What’s driving this huge need for more bandwidth? Video Started It All Video now makes up most of the world’s internet traffic.

item.title: AI Is Going to Eat Your Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler Human communication might not dominate telecom usage for much longer. It started when computers began sharing data over phone lines and sped up when broadband internet connected almost every computer. Even though people currently use the internet for websites, messaging, social media, videos, backups, and work, machines will soon be the primary users, communicating amongst themselves. The Rise of Artificial Intelligence Artificial intelligence, or AI, has been subtly infiltrating our lives for decades, likely since computers emerged.

item.title: VXSuite Takes the Scary Out of VoIP
item.description: By: John Shepler You understand that Unified Communications, powered by VoIP telephony, is the future of business communication. You also recognize its potential to boost productivity. However, the fear of completely overhauling your existing system is holding you back. While your current phones, connected through old wiring, might seem adequate for making and receiving calls, they limit your communication capabilities. To unlock more advanced features, transitioning to an all-IP network is essential.

item.title: Telecom Providers Build Their Own Clouds
item.description: As cloud computing companies start to establish themselves, internet service providers and similar carriers are developing their own cloud services. This creates a challenge for IT professionals and business owners who need to choose the best option. It’s important to recognize that cloud computing is still in its early stages. Like any new technology, it will take time for it to fully develop. As the technology progresses, we will see a lot of activity from many different companies.

item.title: Try Cloud Website Load Testing Free
item.description: You’ve established your online presence, but the question remains: how strong is it? Just like the story of the three little pigs, a website needs to be built with strong materials to withstand the elements. While a website might appear impressive when it’s not in use, the true test comes with a surge of visitors. Load testing is the only way to determine if your site can handle high traffic.

item.title: Business Phone Goes Hosted
item.description: The evolution of business phone systems has progressed from basic single-line setups to intricate PBX systems accommodating numerous phones. However, the latest advancement isn’t about bigger in-house systems but rather a shift towards hosted solutions. Hosted business phone, also known as cloud-based phone service, involves a provider managing your phone system on their equipment. Essentially, the responsibility of operating the PBX and connecting to the public phone network shifts from your company to the provider.

item.title: Broadview Networks OfficeSuite Brings The Cloud To SMB
item.description: Smaller companies often want to adopt money-saving technologies like VoIP, private networks, and cloud services, but the initial investment can be daunting. While internet-based options seem appealing, their quality and reliability are often a concern. Fortunately, there’s a solution for businesses of all sizes to access these advanced tools without breaking the bank. Broadview Networks’ OfficeSuite offers a comprehensive solution, effectively serving as a company’s central office across multiple locations. This enterprise-grade PBX system provides the functionality of a traditional system with the convenience of easy administration through a web browser.

item.title: Avoid DNS Cache Poisoning With UltraDNS
item.description: The Domain Name System, or DNS, is essential for navigating the internet. It translates website names and links into a numerical language that computers understand. As we transition to IPV6, DNS will become even more critical. Fast and dependable DNS services are crucial for anyone online. While these services are typically provided by internet providers and hosting companies, their quality can vary. Some are slow, some update slowly, and others pose security risks.

item.title: Clod Computing Challenges The Cloud
Backup and Recovery For All Businesses
item.description: Businesses are exposed to various risks, not just economic fluctuations or environmental factors. Your data, whether on your computer or in your data center, might be your biggest vulnerability. Without backup and recovery solutions, you’re one mishap away from major problems. Your data is the most valuable asset at risk. While paper records were once the norm, with fire as a primary threat, today’s electronic records face risks like corruption and deletion.

item.title: Low Latency Fiber Routes To Europe and Asia
item.description: Numerous American companies establish branches in the UK and Europe, while multinational corporations operate globally. A prevalent solution for connecting these international offices, including cloud services, is low-latency fiber optic routes. The term “low latency,” once obscure, gained prominence with the shift from traditional phone lines to VoIP. Previously, it primarily described delays in satellite communication. The question arises: why the emphasis on low-latency fiber routes now? Aren’t fiber connections inherently low latency?

item.title: Cloud Based Unified Communications
item.description: Cloud servers have gained widespread acceptance as many IT departments realize the advantages of readily available and scalable processing and storage over predicting hardware needs. Traditional phone systems, however, often face similar challenges. PBX systems, often proprietary and inflexible, require upfront investment in anticipated capacity, leading to either underutilization or costly upgrades. Cloud-based communication offers a solution by moving switching and storage to the cloud, eliminating the need for physical PBX hardware and enabling scalability based on demand.

item.title: Why Demand a SAS 70 Type II Data Center?
item.description: When choosing a cloud or colocation provider, prioritize data privacy and security, especially in regulated sectors like healthcare and finance. A facility with SAS 70 Type II compliance can offer this assurance. SAS 70, based on the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA) Statement on Auditing Standards No. 70, Service Organizations, involves a rigorous audit of a company’s data handling practices by an independent firm. This audit results in a comprehensive written report.

item.title: How Managed SD-WAN Can Help Your Business
item.description: By: John Shepler Going digital can be great for business until you hit roadblocks trying to make it work. One of these unexpected hurdles is the need for way more internet bandwidth than you anticipated. You can struggle to make it work without going bankrupt, or you can use managed SD-WAN to make your connectivity invisible. Why Is Connectivity Such a Big Deal Now? When your business was primarily physical, a standard broadband connection for internet access was probably enough.

item.title: The PBX Disappears With Hosted Voice
item.description: Mid-size and large businesses are accustomed to managing their in-house phone systems, believing that a PBX or Key telephone system is necessary for internal calls. Hosted voice service challenges this notion, requiring only the phones themselves and sometimes providing even those. Hosted Voice, also called Hosted VoIP or Hosted PBX, is a cloud-based service. The PBX system still exists but resides at the service provider’s location, not yours. This model resembles what companies used decades ago when telephone service was provided by a single entity like Bell System.

item.title: The Rush To Cloud Service Data Centers
item.description: Many companies are moving away from managing their own servers and rapidly shifting towards public data centers. This article explores the reasons behind this trend and its potential future. Cost savings have always been a major driver for companies considering data center colocation. Instead of investing in their own data centers, companies can move their equipment to a colocation facility. These facilities provide economies of scale by housing servers and network devices from multiple companies, sharing the costs of cooling, power, security, and bandwidth.

item.title: Can Satellite Be Part of Your SD-WAN?
item.description: By: John Shepler Software Defined Networks (SDN) and Software Defined Wide Area Networks (SD-WAN) are seeing increased implementation due to their ability to offer cost-effective, high-quality bandwidth for businesses. SD-WAN is sometimes the sole option for acceptable bandwidth in remote or rural locations. These software-defined networks act as a blend of various connection technologies, intelligently maximizing the use of each available connection, including satellite. The Need For SD Networks Traditionally, connecting to the internet or a cloud service provider involved ordering a “last mile” connection from a business location or a dedicated point-to-point line between two points, like an office and a cloud provider.

item.title: Bandwidth on Demand Complements Cloud Services
item.description: By: John Shepler One of the biggest advantages of cloud services over traditional IT infrastructure is their flexibility. With a vast pool of virtual servers and storage, businesses can adjust resources on demand, significantly improving productivity and resource usage. However, connectivity hasn’t quite caught up with this shift. Connecting to the cloud often relies on fixed-capacity connections. Upgrading these connections is typically a complex and time-consuming process, creating a bottleneck in an otherwise agile system.

item.title: The Green Way To Get Documents Signed
item.description: The excessive paperwork in business today contradicts early predictions of a paperless office. Despite the rise of computers, high-speed printers led to increased printing, resulting in a cycle of paper consumption and shredding. Cloud services offer a potential solution by enabling work processes that don’t rely on physical documents. While some businesses transition to online operations, others remain partially offline, necessitating physical documents for legal and operational purposes. This reliance on paper persists due to the need for legally valid signatures on agreements, forms, and contracts, as digital communication methods are often insufficient.

item.title: Finding Lit Buildings and Near Net Fiber Buildings
item.description: By: John Shepler Fiber optic internet service is becoming increasingly essential for modern businesses, but not everyone has access to it. Some businesses don’t need the high speeds fiber offers and are content with slower options. Others might have outdated perceptions of fiber’s affordability. Many are unaware that fiber might already be available in their building or nearby. Fiber optic internet isn’t the niche product it once was. Even consumers are demanding fiber to their homes for streaming and entertainment.

item.title: Broadband for the Bandwidth Starved
item.description: By: John Shepler While it’s evident that we exist in a connected world, not everyone enjoys the optimal level of connectivity. Some areas remain underserved, lacking sufficient bandwidth. So, what can be done if you find yourself in such a situation? Don’t Worry, Broadband Exists! In the past, broadband access was limited to specific areas, leaving many with only dial-up connections. Fortunately, the situation has significantly improved, with broadband internet access now available in most places.

item.title: Cloud Based Services With Free Trial Offers
item.description: Numerous businesses are turning to cloud services to reduce capital expenses and ongoing operational costs. This rapidly growing field has many vendors vying for market share, making it challenging to determine the ideal services for your needs. For small businesses with limited budgets, ensuring maximum value for their IT and communication spending is crucial. One effective approach is to test services through free trials before committing. With this in mind, we’ve compiled a list of cloud-based services offering trial periods.

item.title: Helping Your Business Achieve Hyperconnectivity
item.description: By: John Shepler It took a whole generation to connect the entire world to the internet. Now, get ready for an even bigger change: we’re moving towards hyperconnectivity, and it’s happening fast. Everything, Everywhere, All at Once Hyperconnectivity means that anything and anyone who can be connected will be connected all the time. We’ve already shifted from logging in to having always-on internet for our computers and phones. The next step is to let our devices communicate with each other without us.

item.title: Managed Hosting in Clouds and Colos
item.description: There are many hosting choices available. Shared hosting is popular among individuals and small businesses due to its affordability and acceptable performance. However, as your needs grow, you face a decision: self-hosting or a managed solution. While setting up a website previously required technical expertise in server management, Linux and Windows hosting have become increasingly user-friendly and widely accessible. Even large enterprises accustomed to managing their servers in-house are reconsidering colocation and cloud solutions, driven by cost and resource optimization.

item.title: Get Your Building Fiber Lit For Free
item.description: Fiber optic bandwidth is currently available at excellent prices. Although many companies are eager to upgrade to faster internet speeds like Fast Ethernet (100 Mbps), GigE (1000 Mbps), or even 10 Gigabit Ethernet, the construction costs to install fiber optic service in their buildings are often prohibitive. However, there’s a possibility to have your building fiber lit without any construction costs. The secret is that certain competitive carriers are willing to cover construction expenses to meet the rising demand for high-bandwidth services.

item.title: FastE Is The New DS3
item.description: Businesses that need more bandwidth than their T1 lines can provide have usually upgraded to DS3. However, a faster and more affordable option, Fast Ethernet (FastE), is now available. While you might not know Fast Ethernet as a Metro or Carrier bandwidth service, the term is likely familiar. Fast Ethernet refers to 100 Mbps Ethernet, one of the standard LAN speeds alongside 10 Mbps and 1,000 Mbps Ethernet (Gigabit Ethernet or GigE).

item.title: The Value of Low Latency Fiber Optic Connections
item.description: By: John Shepler Slow network speeds, particularly when connecting to the internet or other company sites, could point to a latency problem. Let’s explore how businesses and organizations can achieve faster network connections: For businesses that rely on high-speed network performance, like high-frequency financial trading, minimizing latency is crucial. Some companies even choose to be in the same building as stock exchanges to be just feet away from servers. While most applications aren’t that demanding, factors like bandwidth, latency, packet loss, and jitter still matter.

item.title: ElephantDrive Never Forgets Your Files
item.description: Elephants are known for their impressive memory. What if you could harness that power for your data? ElephantDrive is an online storage service that offers the digital equivalent of an elephant’s memory. ElephantDrive provides unlimited, encrypted storage that’s easily accessible and budget-friendly for individuals and businesses. Think of it as storage in the cloud. This offsite backup ensures your data’s safety, even if disaster strikes your primary location. Imagine losing your computer and backups to a tornado.

item.title: Tips To Reduce Your Telecom Costs
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses are facing a challenging time as they grapple with the fluctuating economic landscape brought on by the Covid-19 crisis. While growth was once the primary focus, survival has now taken center stage, making cost control paramount. Let’s explore some immediate steps you can take to reduce expenses without jeopardizing operations. Are You Paying For Unused Services? It might seem improbable, but both individuals and businesses frequently pay for services they don’t utilize.

item.title: Same Budget, More Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler Is Slow Network Speed Affecting Your Business? Are you experiencing frustrating network issues like slow downloads, choppy calls, interrupted streaming, and sluggish website loading? Do You Need More Bandwidth? There’s a good chance your internet connection needs more bandwidth. While your internal network might be fast enough, your external connection (WAN) might not be able to handle your current needs. Signs You Need More Bandwidth If your internet service hasn’t changed in years but your business relies more on multimedia and online tools, you probably need more bandwidth.

item.title: A Visual Guide To Enterprise VoIP Justification
item.description: Thank you to MegaPath Broadband Service Providers for this interesting infographic. Is your company missing out on the advantages of enterprise VoIP technology, which can potentially reduce costs and increase productivity? A variety of on-site and hosted options are available to accommodate businesses of all sizes. Explore business VoIP solutions and pricing from MegaPath and other providers.

item.title: Your 50 Mbps WAN Bandwidth Options
item.description: By: John Shepler The need for 50 Mbps bandwidth has increased due to businesses needing to use cloud services, access remote data centers, transfer large data files, run e-commerce platforms, send high-resolution images, and distribute video content. There are various ways to get 50 Mbps bandwidth connectivity, each with its own benefits and drawbacks. DS3 & T3 DS3, or T3, is a traditional telecom service designed for transmitting many calls simultaneously between switching centers.

item.title: MegaPath Puts Your Complete Office In The Cloud
